articles.description: How and why do we gender animals in stories?
articles.title: Bears Will Be Boys

articles.description: Watch hundreds of strangers talk for 30 minutes, and track how their moods change
articles.title: 30 minutes with a stranger

articles.description: A 6 minute video about the loneliness epidemic, in data
articles.title: The Loneliness Epidemic, in Data

articles.description: How accurately are Asian Americans cast in Hollywood?
articles.title: Asian Misrepresentation

articles.description: Are you more likely to die on your birthday? Yes.
articles.title: Are you more likely to die on your birthday?

articles.description: We try to predict the price and quality of a bottle of wine based on the animal on the label.
articles.title: The Pour-igin of Species

articles.author: Joseph Howlett
articles.description:
After just a few months of work, a complete newcomer to the world of sphere packing has solved one of its biggest open problems.            
The post New Sphere-Packing Record Stems From an Unexpected Source first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: New Sphere-Packing Record Stems From an Unexpected Source

articles.author: Yasemin Saplakoglu
articles.description:
A better understanding of human smell is emerging as scientists interrogate its fundamental elements: the odor molecules that enter your nose and the individual neurons that translate them into perception in your brain.            
The post How Smell Guides Our Inner World first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How Smell Guides Our Inner World

articles.author: Jenna Ahart
articles.description:
The precursors of heavy elements might arise in the plasma underbellies of swollen stars or in smoldering stellar corpses. They definitely exist in East Lansing, Michigan.            
The post Physicists Start To Pin Down How Stars Forge Heavy Atoms first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Physicists Start To Pin Down How Stars Forge Heavy Atoms

articles.author: Webb Wright
articles.description:
Image generators are designed to mimic their training data, so where does their apparent creativity come from? A recent study suggests that it’s an inevitable by-product of their architecture.            
The post Researchers Uncover Hidden Ingredients Behind AI Creativity first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Researchers Uncover Hidden Ingredients Behind AI Creativity

articles.author: Molly Herring
articles.description:
Scientists reconstructed 500 million years of evolutionary history to reveal which came first: colorful signals or the color vision needed to see them.             
The post When Did Nature Burst Into Vivid Color? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: When Did Nature Burst Into Vivid Color?

articles.author: Janna Levin and Steven Strogatz
articles.description:
Maria Chudnovsky reflects on her journey in graph theory, her groundbreaking solution to the long-standing perfect graph problem, and the unexpected ways this abstract field intersects with everyday life.            
The post How Does Graph Theory Shape Our World? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How Does Graph Theory Shape Our World?

articles.author: Elise Cutts
articles.description:
A tetrahedron is the simplest Platonic solid. Mathematicians have now made one that’s stable only on one side, confirming a decades-old conjecture.            
The post A New Pyramid-Like Shape Always Lands the Same Side Up first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: A New Pyramid-Like Shape Always Lands the Same Side Up

articles.author: Matt von Hippel
articles.description:
Every elementary particle falls into one of two categories. Collectivist bosons account for the forces that move us while individualist fermions keep our atoms from collapsing.            
The post Matter vs. Force: Why There Are Exactly Two Types of Particles first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Matter vs. Force: Why There Are Exactly Two Types of Particles

articles.author: Gregory Barber
articles.description:
Two new notions of infinity challenge a long-standing plan to define the mathematical universe.            
The post Is Mathematics Mostly Chaos or Mostly Order? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Is Mathematics Mostly Chaos or Mostly Order?

articles.author: Eric James Beyer
articles.description:
Martin Schrimpf is crafting bespoke AI models that can induce control over high-level brain activity.             
The post How AI Models Are Helping to Understand — and Control — the Brain first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How AI Models Are Helping to Understand — and Control — the Brain

articles.author: Gabriel Popkin
articles.description:
By speedrunning ecosystems with microbes, researchers revealed intrinsic properties that may make a community susceptible to invasion.            
The post The Ecosystem Dynamics That Can Make or Break an Invasion first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: The Ecosystem Dynamics That Can Make or Break an Invasion

articles.author: George Musser
articles.description:
A new argument explores how the growth of disorder could cause massive objects to move toward one another. Physicists are both interested and skeptical.            
The post Is Gravity Just Entropy Rising? Long-Shot Idea Gets Another Look. first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Is Gravity Just Entropy Rising? Long-Shot Idea Gets Another Look.

articles.author: Janna Levin and Steven Strogatz
articles.description:
From brain folds to insect architecture, L. Mahadevan explains how complex biological forms and behaviors emerge through the interplay of physical forces, environment and embodiment.            
The post Does Form Really Shape Function? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Does Form Really Shape Function?

articles.author: Leila Sloman
articles.description:
By mathematically proving how individual molecules create the complex motion of fluids, three mathematicians have illuminated why time can’t flow in reverse.            
The post Epic Effort to Ground Physics in Math Opens Up the Secrets of Time first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Epic Effort to Ground Physics in Math Opens Up the Secrets of Time

articles.author: Stephen Ornes
articles.description:
The catch: It would require the energy of a few medium-size stars.            
The post New Quantum Algorithm Factors Numbers With One Qubit first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: New Quantum Algorithm Factors Numbers With One Qubit

articles.author: Shalma Wegsman
articles.description:
Physicists recently mapped the hidden shape that underlies the quantum behaviors of a crystal, using a new method that’s expected to become ubiquitous.            
The post First Map Made of a Solid’s Secret Quantum Geometry first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: First Map Made of a Solid’s Secret Quantum Geometry

articles.author: Conor Feehly
articles.description:
Studies of neural metabolism reveal our brain’s effort to keep us alive and the evolutionary constraints that sculpted our most complex organ.            
The post How Much Energy Does It Take To Think? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How Much Energy Does It Take To Think?

articles.author: Joseph Howlett
articles.description:
By extending the scope of the key insight behind Fermat’s Last Theorem, four mathematicians have made great strides toward building a “grand unified theory” of math.            
The post The Core of Fermat’s Last Theorem Just Got Superpowered first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: The Core of Fermat’s Last Theorem Just Got Superpowered

articles.author: Matt von Hippel
articles.description:
Reversible programs run backward as easily as they run forward, saving energy in theory. After decades of research, they may soon power AI.            
The post How Can AI Researchers Save Energy? By Going Backward. first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How Can AI Researchers Save Energy? By Going Backward.

articles.author: Janna Levin and Steven Strogatz
articles.description:
Promise and controversy continues to surround string theory as a potential unified theory of everything. In the latest episode of The Joy of Why, Cumrun Vafa discusses his progress in trying to find good, testable models hidden among the ‘swampland’ of impossible universes.            
The post Will We Ever Prove String Theory? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Will We Ever Prove String Theory?

articles.author: Molly Herring
articles.description:
Manu Prakash works on the world’s most urgent problems and seemingly frivolous questions at the same time. They add up to a philosophy he calls “recreational biology.”            
The post How Paradoxical Questions and Simple Wonder Lead to Great Science first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How Paradoxical Questions and Simple Wonder Lead to Great Science

articles.author: Charlie Wood
articles.description:
Black hole and Big Bang singularities break our best theory of gravity. A trilogy of theorems hints that physicists must go to the ends of space and time to find a fix.             
The post Singularities in Space-Time Prove Hard to Kill first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Singularities in Space-Time Prove Hard to Kill

articles.author: Leila Sloman
articles.description:
A new proof illuminates the hidden patterns that emerge when addition becomes impossible.            
The post Graduate Student Solves Classic Problem About the Limits of Addition first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Graduate Student Solves Classic Problem About the Limits of Addition

articles.author: Ben Brubaker
articles.description:
One computer scientist’s “stunning” proof is the first progress in 50 years on one of the most famous questions in computer science.            
The post For Algorithms, a Little Memory Outweighs a Lot of Time first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: For Algorithms, a Little Memory Outweighs a Lot of Time

articles.author: Elizabeth Landau
articles.description:
Slight changes in the number, shape, efficiency and interconnectedness of organelles in the cells of flight muscles provide extra energy for birds’ continent-spanning feats.            
The post ‘Turbocharged’ Mitochondria Power Birds’ Epic Migratory Journeys first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: ‘Turbocharged’ Mitochondria Power Birds’ Epic Migratory Journeys

articles.author: Joseph Howlett
articles.description:
Turbulence is a notoriously difficult phenomenon to study. Mathematicians are now starting to untangle it at its smallest scales.            
The post New ‘Superdiffusion’ Proof Probes the Mysterious Math of Turbulence first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: New ‘Superdiffusion’ Proof Probes the Mysterious Math of Turbulence

articles.author: Janna Levin and Steven Strogatz
articles.description:
Geometry may have its origins thousands of years ago in ancient land surveying, but it has also had a surprising impact on modern physics. In the latest episode of The Joy of Why, Yang-Hui He explores geometry’s evolution and its future potential through AI.            
The post How Did Geometry Create Modern Physics? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How Did Geometry Create Modern Physics?

articles.author: Zack Savitsky
articles.description:
From living matter to molecules to elementary particles, the world is made of “chiral” objects that differ from their reflected forms.            
The post How the Universe Differs From Its Mirror Image first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How the Universe Differs From Its Mirror Image

articles.description: Inside PRO's rapid effort to connect private donors with the most cost-effective programs affected by USAID cuts.
articles.title: How to Triage $35 Billion in Aid Cuts

articles.description: Google Android’s calculator is (probably) the most widely used calculator in the world. It’s also the most advanced.
articles.title: The Impossible Calculator

articles.description: Few thinkers have been championed by such a wide range of political coalitions, from American Progressives to Taiwanese anti-communists, early zionists to the global Green Party. So how did American libertarianism come to embrace Henry George, too?
articles.title: The Georgist Roots of American Libertarianism

articles.description: “Cancer is extremely varied and adaptive, and is likely the hardest of these diseases to fully destroy.” — Dario Amodei
articles.title: Knockout Mouse

articles.description: The idea of cryonics — freezing the bodies of the dead in the hopes that they can one day be revived — has existed since the 1960s. We’ve since learned that perfect preservation is much, much harder than any of its founders anticipated.
articles.title: Brain Freeze

articles.description: Universities have existed for more than a thousand years — and for almost all of that time, they weren’t centers of research. What changed in 19th century Germany?
articles.title: The Origin of the Research University

articles.description: When we try and pick out any technology in isolation, we find it hitched, in some way, to every innovation that preceded it. (Except for the Oldowan hand axe. We had to start somewhere.)
articles.title: The Universal Tech Tree

articles.description: The modern education system around the world continues to bear the imprint of mass education’s original goal: obedience.
articles.title: What Are Schools For?

articles.description: America’s roads are more dangerous than those of almost every country in the developed world. We know how to change that.
articles.title: Traffic Fatalities Are a Choice

articles.description: Building a high-speed rail between Los Angeles and San Francisco was never going to be easy — but the critics who write it off are missing the real source of the project’s struggles.
articles.title: Reports of the Death of  California High-Speed Rail Have Been Greatly Exaggerated

articles.description: Everyone likes the idea of evidence-based policy, but it’s hard to realize it when our most reputable social science journals are still publishing poor quality research.
articles.title: Can We Trust Social Science Yet?

articles.description: A conversation about the factors that might slow down the pace of AI development, what could happen next, and whether we’ll be able to see it coming.
articles.title: Does AI Progress Have a Speed Limit?

articles.description: Kelsey Piper and Jasmine Sun talk about microschools, whether localism is the enemy of Abundance, and why Chinese bureaucrats are like Growth PMs.
articles.title: Does Abundance Start at Home?

articles.author: Asimov Press
articles.description: A science fiction story brought to life through a pro-GMO dinner.
articles.title: A Night of Food Futurism

articles.author: Eric Gilliam
articles.description: An interview with Ilan Gur, CEO of ARIA, about the organization’s efforts to build scientific waves.
articles.title: Inside ARIA, the UK's Bet to Build Scientific Revolutions

articles.author: Asimov Press
articles.description: Prominent scientists continue to claim life is “just” slime on a spinning rock. However, in an age when the rarity and fragility of life are increasingly evident, it’s time to retire the metaphor.
articles.title: Life as Slime

articles.author: Evan DeTurk
articles.description: A selected encyclopedia of major gene-editing systems, together with illustrated diagrams.
articles.title: A Visual Guide to Genome Editors

articles.author: Spencer Nitkey - Writer
articles.description: Bioart emerges where biological science, technology, and aesthetics collide. For one terminally ill artist, it offered a chance at immortality.
articles.title: The Eternal Life and Art of Maxwell Ardeen

articles.author: Asimov Press
articles.description: Toxic amino acids, peptides, and proteins — which first evolved as molecular weapons deployed by species in conflict — can also serve as blueprints for pharmaceutical innovation.
articles.title: Toxic Proteins for Drug Discovery

articles.description: By studying the millennia-old arms race between soil-dwelling microbes, scientists can pre-empt antibiotic resistance before it emerges in people.
articles.title: Reservoirs of Resistance

articles.author: Deena Mousa
articles.description: We have the technology to detect airborne pathogens in real time. Now we must use it.
articles.title: Keeping Ahead of Contagion

articles.description: A research study reveals that some vertebrate genomes mutate 40-times faster than others.
articles.title: Model Organisms Are Not Static

articles.author: Niko McCarty
articles.description: A decades-old essay offers newfound appreciation for progress.
articles.title: Seven Wonders of Biology

articles.author: dynomight
articles.description: Answering this question may seem straightforward, but actually requires an odyssey through information theory and molecular biology.
articles.title: How Much Information is in DNA?

articles.author: Asimov Press
articles.description: The modern centrifuge was first designed for milkfat separation in the dairy industry. Today, it is ubiquitous in research laboratories. To whom do we owe its astonishing versatility?
articles.title: Making the Centrifuge

articles.author: Smrithi Sunil
articles.description: How a chance discovery in bioluminescent jellyfish led to one of the most transformative tools in modern biology: green fluorescent protein.
articles.title: A Brief History of GFP

articles.author: Hiya Jain
articles.description: In 2017, there were just over 600 clinical trials initiated in China. By 2023, that number was nearly 2,000. How can American companies kick off a similar boom?
articles.title: China’s Clinical Trial Boom

articles.author: Alexandra Balwit
articles.description: With a litany of gene therapies and longevity medicine staving off biological death, those paid to write about it must reimagine their craft.
articles.title: Eulogy to the Obits

articles.description: Some researchers claim that a Chilean vine can mimic the leaves of a plastic houseplant thanks to a form of primitive vision. But extraordinary claims require equally extraordinary evidence.
articles.title: Can Plants Really “See”?

articles.author: Stephen Malina
articles.description: Why biologists should operate with a sense of urgency.
articles.title: The Magic of Fast Feedback Loops

articles.description:
His alleged victims say he bribed New York Police Department officials, stole millions in diamonds, and persuaded Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Kim Kardashian to shill for a scam cryptocurrency. So why is Jona Rechnitz still free?
The post All That Glitters appeared first on The Atavist Magazine.

articles.author: Stephen Wolfram
articles.description: Cats Don’t Talk We humans have perhaps 100 billion neurons in our brains. But what if we had many more? Or what if the AIs we built effectively had many more? What kinds of things might then become possible? At 100 billion neurons, we know, for example, that compositional language of the kind we humans […]
articles.title: What If We Had Bigger Brains? Imagining Minds beyond Ours

articles.author: Tovin Lapan
articles.description: Pizzeria da Laura and Middle East Market have both expanded into neighboring spaces to offer something different to customers.
articles.title: In Berkeley, a market opens a restaurant, and a restaurant opens a market

articles.author: Alex N. Gecan
articles.description: Ramp and lane closures will last from 9 p.m. Thursday until 6 a.m. Friday. Caltrans recommended using the Gilman Street or Ashby Avenue exits.
articles.title: Westbound I-80 exit at University Ave. to close overnight Thursday in Berkeley

articles.author: Alex N. Gecan
articles.description: A spokesperson for the East Bay Regional Park District said that there was no foul play suspected. The man was in his 20s.
articles.title: Dead man found Sunday near Berkeley waterfront

articles.author: Natalie Orenstein and Alex N. Gecan
articles.description: County officials may be at odds over how to spend hundreds of millions from Measure W, a sales tax marketed to voters as funding shelters and housing.
articles.title: Tax money is flowing into Alameda County. Should it all be spent on homelessness?

articles.author: Frances Dinkelspiel
articles.description: Rich Lyons is preparing to testify before a U.S. House committee investigating on-campus “antisemitism upheaval and hatred” in a hearing with huge stakes both for Cal and the wider UC system.
articles.title: UC Berkeley chancellor is prepping for Capitol Hill grilling

articles.author: Adam Echelman | CalMatters
articles.description: Men's basketball players at Cal could make an average of $200,000 a year, football players $100,000 and women's basketball players $60,000.
articles.title: UC Berkeley can now pay athletes directly

articles.author: Nathan Dalton
articles.description: Lishq, offering Indian jewelry with a “modern twist,” is in the same building as Shelly and Deepak Ajmani’s spice shop — in the spot where a different jewelry store closed last year after an armed robbery.
articles.title: Bombay Spice Shop owners open jewelry and wedding supply store

articles.author: Family of Bobby Moore
articles.description: A cab driver in San Francisco for over half a century, he was known for his stories, his laughter, and his encyclopedic knowledge of the city.
articles.title: Remembering Bobby Moore, abstract artist, storyteller, longtime cab driver

articles.author: Family of Dan Siegel
articles.description: Siegel later served as president of Oakland's school board and fought for workers, unions, and human rights advocates over five decades as a civil rights lawyer.
articles.title: Remembering Dan Siegel, who told the crowd to take People’s Park on Bloody Thursday

articles.author: EdSource and Vanessa Arredondo
articles.description: The Trump administration froze $6.2 billion in federal education grants, including $811 million that was to fund teacher training, migrant education, and after-school programs in California.
articles.title: $400K for Berkeley schools in limbo after Trump’s grant freeze

articles.author: Karina Ioffee
articles.description: Local leaders warn the bill’s $1.2 trillion cuts to Medicaid and food stamps will hit hard in Alameda County, where one in three residents relies on Medi-Cal and one in 10 rely on food stamps.
articles.title: ‘This is draconian’: Trump’s big bill expected to bring more hunger, sickness, homelessness to Berkeley

articles.author: Vanessa Arredondo
articles.description: Officials urge caution in sharing unconfirmed sightings.
articles.title: Berkeley residents are on edge over unverified reports of ICE in the city

articles.author: Nathan Dalton
articles.description: It’s the second big Berkeley bookstore closure this year. A spokesperson for Half Price Books attributed the closure to a lease dispute with their landlord.
articles.title: Half Price Books will close its downtown Berkeley store after 20 years

articles.author: Berkeleyside Staff
articles.description: BPD investigated three reports of gunfire in June alone. City and university police previously investigated five other instances of gunfire this year, one with injuries.
articles.title: 2025 Berkeley gunfire map: Eight investigations halfway through year

articles.author: Iris Kwok and Andrew Gilbert
articles.description: Other events include a Berkeley Latin Jazz Collective performance at North Beach Pizza and a new crochet club at Bobby G's Pizzeria.
articles.title: Around Berkeley: Shakespeare’s ‘Cymbeline’ in the park, matcha workshop, Blake Garden tour

articles.author: Family of Kathy Paxson
articles.description: Inquisitive and present, Rawson loved nature, pets and cooking and was active in the Berkeley Community Chorus and Orchestra and in Bella Musica.
articles.title: Remembering Kathy Paxson, financial manager, crafter, creator of songs and games

articles.author: Berkeleyside Staff
articles.description: Also: Abraham Chabon, an NYU student who grew up in Berkeley, has been charged with rape in Manhattan.
articles.title: Berkeley Wire: Cal builds new 7-story parking garage; city’s priciest home sale of 2025; watch out for coyotes
